title: Luigi Cevenini
text:
Luigi Cevenini (; 13 March 1895 – 23 July 1968) was an Italian <a href="football%20%28soccer%29">football</a> player and <a href="Association%20football%20manager">coach</a> who played as a <a href="Forward%20%28association%20football%29">forward</a>.
Club career.
Throughout his career, Cevenini played 190 times for <a href="Internazionale%20Milano%20F.C.">Internazionale</a> and scored 186 goals, winning the Italian Prima Divisione title in 1920.
The height of his individual career though was, while playing for <a href="Juventus%20F.C.">Juventus Football Club</a>, not so much because of his 3 top 3 seasons but because he reached the top of his <a href="Italy%20national%20football%20team">Italy</a> career, while a <a href="Juventus">Juventus</a> player.
International career.
With the <a href="Italy%20national%20football%20team">Italy national football team</a>, Cevenini scored 11 goals in 29 matches between 1915 and 1929, winning the <a href="1927%E2%80%9330%20Central%20European%20International%20Cup">1927–30 Central European International Cup</a>, playing the first 2 matches. He was Italy's <a href="Captain%20%28association%20football%29">captain</a> between 1925 and 1927.
Personal life.
His older brothers <a href="Aldo%20Cevenini">Aldo Cevenini</a> and <a href="Mario%20Cevenini">Mario Cevenini</a> and younger brothers <a href="Cesare%20Cevenini">Cesare Cevenini</a> and <a href="Carlo%20Cevenini">Carlo Cevenini</a> all played football professionally, with Aldo playing 11 games for <a href="Italy%20national%20football%20team">Italy</a>. To distinguish them, Aldo was known as Cevenini I, Mario as Cevenini II, Luigi as Cevenini III, Cesare as Cevenini IV and Carlo as Cevenini V.
